Use when you need probabilistic batch correction (scVI), transfer learning, differential expression with uncertainty, or multi-modal integration (TOTALVI, MultiVI). Best for advanced modeling, batch effects, multimodal data. For standard analysis pipelines use scanpy.

content.user_title: Analyze single-cell genomics with deep probabilistic models
content.value_statement: Single-cell data analysis requires sophisticated statistical models to handle noise, batch effects, and multimodal measurements. scvi-tools provides deep generative models that automatically correct technical variations while preserving biological signals.
actual_capabilities: Cell type annotation with transfer learning
limitations: Models must be trained before analysis

use_cases.title: Perform spatial transcriptomics deconvolution

best_practices: Always use raw count data, not log-normalized or scaled values
Include known batch variables in setup_anndata() for proper correction
Filter low-quality cells and genes before training models
anti_patterns: Using normalized data as input - models need raw counts
Ignoring batch effects - always register technical covariates
Training on full gene set - use highly variable genes for efficiency

faq.question: What data format does scvi-tools require?
faq.answer: scvi-tools uses AnnData format. Ensure your data has raw counts in adata.X or adata.layers['counts']

faq.question: Do I need a GPU to use scvi-tools?
faq.answer: GPU is recommended for datasets >10,000 cells but not required. CPU training works for smaller datasets

faq.question: How do I save and load trained models?
faq.answer: Use model.save('path/') to save and scvi.model.ModelClass.load('path/', adata=adata) to load

faq.question: Can I use scvi-tools with scanpy?
faq.answer: Yes, scvi-tools integrates seamlessly with scanpy. Store outputs in adata.obsm for downstream analysis

faq.question: What's the difference between scVI and scANVI?
faq.answer: scVI is unsupervised for batch correction and clustering. scANVI uses cell type labels for semi-supervised integration

faq.question: How long does training take?
faq.answer: Training time scales with dataset size. Typical runtime: 1-2 hours for 100k cells on GPU, 6-12 hours on CPU
